title: `BufReader::Seek` should not flush the buffer when seeking to `SeekFrom::Current(0)`

labels.name: T-libs
labels.description: Relevant to the library team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-io
labels.description: Area: std::io, std::fs, std::net and std::path

body:
The documentation for `BufReader` states that

> Seeking always discards the internal buffer, even if the seek position would otherwise fall within it. This guarantees that calling `BufReader::into_inner()` immediately after a seek yields the underlying reader at the same position.

and this is true both with implementation of `BufReader` on [the current stable](https://doc.rust-lang.org/src/std/io/buffered/bufreader.rs.html#370-393) (1.53.0 as of the time of writing) and on [the current nightly](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/798baebde1fe77e5a660490ec64e727a5d79970d/library/std/src/io/buffered/bufreader.rs#L370-L393) (798baebde1fe77e5a660490ec64e727a5d79970d as of the time of writing).

However, this rationale does not apply when seeking to `SeekFrom::Current(0)`, which is commonly used to find the current seek position in a stream. A program that repeatedly obtains the seek position will repeatedly flush the buffer and lose many of the benefits associated with having a `BufReader` in the first place. Instead, since `SeekFrom::Current(0)` does not change the position of the Seek cursor, `BufReader` can get the current position via `self.inner.seek(SeekFrom::Current(0))` and return this result, avoiding flushing the buffer (and its associated performance costs).

If you would like actual code where this issue arises, please let me know and I can follow up with sample code in which using `BufReader` is several times slower than direct reads.

(I consider this to be a performance bug, but if this would be more appropriate as a feature request, please let me know so that I can repost this to the correct forum(s).)
